ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: It rebuilt my foundation of vocabulary and grammar of Latin.
Built upon grammar and translating skills through the interesting readings of Cicero and Seneca
Continuation of reading Latin prose, but with a lot of helpful information about the history of the authors and Rome.
Latin grammar, prose, and the historical context related to our readings. Also just a lot of fun translating Cicero and Seneca!

We covered Cicero's Pro Archia for the first half of the semester, and selections from Seneca (Consolatio ad Helviam, Ad Consolatio) for the second half of the semester. I learned how to better translate and analyze Latin prose. We also reviewed Latin grammar topics. We had quizzes on translations and grammar, and the exams covered both as well.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: Anna is a great instructor, her approach to teaching really helped me solidify Latin grammar and concepts throughout the semester, fun readings Weaknesses: none

Strengths: The passages we read were interesting and gave a range of the history of Rome and Roman authors
Weaknesses: Sometimes the daily translations were a little monotonous and it was easy to just do them for the credit, but not actually understand/critically think about the text we were reading
Strength: The translations were fun. Cicero in particular was a lot of fun to work with. The translations were also helpful in allowing us to understand various grammatical constructions better.
Gave me a solid foundation in translating Latin prose. Classes can be a little repetitive because of the frequency of translation.

Anna was a great instructor  she made the class very accessible to different backgrounds of introductory Latin, gave good feedback, and was very communicative over email. You definitely have to put time into the course (the translations due every class period MWF can take a while + studying for the quizzes/exams 
+ doing the take-home assignments) but it's very fair overall. I also enjoyed how the course covered the historical context of the works we read and had some Roman history and culture lessons. The final project (picking a Latin passage, translating it, and writing a commentary) was also fun to complete. No weaknesses.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: This is a great Latin course for students that took Latin in high school but maybe not the AP and need a bit of a refresher before learning new content again.
I would recommend this course to another student. It is so satisfying to see everything you have learned from previous years come together in translating prominent ancient texts.
This is a good class to take if you are on the Latin path for your language
Yes if you are interested in Latin and Latin prose in particularly.
I would, if the student is truly interested in Latin translation.
Yes, if you're interested in getting better at translating Latin prose (or if you just need your L3 language credit).
